direction.raw_text: The photos include a sepia-tone portrait of an Italian immigrant family... a b&w snapshot of ROBERTA, a nine-year- old girl playing violin in front of a refrigerator (1950)... ...Roberta and her dashing Italian father, hand-carving a wooden music stand... a b&w snapshot of Roberta in a communion dress... Roberta at 15, playing violin in front of the same refrigerator, eyes on the music stand... ...a color photo of two cute blonde little boys building a sandcastle on a beach... a color photo of a groom in a white naval uniform and his pretty bride, (Roberta at 25), her hand over his as they cut their wedding cake with a sword... ...a color photo of Roberta and her husband Greek dancing with another couple at an outdoor taverna. Roberta's husband and the other man's sexy wife are exchanging a slight smile...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (goading her) Who did you vote for in the last election?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does that have to do with anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hesitates, then) I don't know. Charles filled out my absentee ballot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my God -- it's even worse than I thought! (touching her hair) Is this the same Roberta who got the orchestra to strike until they gave us new uniforms?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That Roberta's not around anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't believe that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what's your husband doing right now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sun streams into the room as Roberta awakens in Brian's bed, a look of afterglow on her face. She suddenly remembers where she is, and quickly looks at the clock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns, relieved, until she sees that Brian's packing a suitcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He dashes out. Roberta sits up, rattled by this news.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh shit -- the boys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) They're still sleeping.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Texas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brian excitedly gathers papers and files scattered around his electric typewriter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns to see Roberta in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He places items into a carry-on bag, packing at a rapid clip. In contrast, Roberta seems to be moving in slow motion.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) What's in Texas?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Farm workers. I just got the call -- it came through -- my research grant! It came through! Isn't that great?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got a few families lined up there, some in California -- ROBERTA How long will you be gone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two, three months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brian throws toiletries into a plastic bag. Roberta enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops what he's doing and looks at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see in her face that part of her did think that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brian softens as he sees how vulnerable she is. He takes her in his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She attempts a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He kisses her forehead, then exits. HOLD ON ROBERTA, looking hurt and frightened.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I thought... I just thought you were gonna be around. And then last night --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whoa. Roberta -- last night was great but did you think I was gonna marry you in the morning?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! Of course not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's just that... we just got here and we're barely... I don't even know where to buy groceries.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're gonna be fine. You have a job, a place to stay, your kids have a school to go to -- and there's a D'Agostino's around the corner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Congratulations.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Roberta rosins her bow, standing in front of ten kids -- third through fifth-grade -- who sit on the floor next to their violin cases. The kids are Black and Latino, with a couple of white faces. They're all talking and ignoring Roberta except for NAEEM and GUADALUPE, a petite Mexican girl with a long dark braid. [NOTE: We'll see other violin students from time to time, but this is the class we'll follow for Roberta's first year]
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kids quiet down. Only Naeem raises his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again, only Naeem raises his hand. Roberta sees him but turns to DE SEAN, who's talking to his neighbor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This makes De Sean blush -- and it pisses him off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some kids giggle and joke about this. Roberta points to the scroll of the violin.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And what am I doing now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rosining the bow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. And what am I doing when I turn this little screw? (raising her voice) Everyone stop talking. Right now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Naeem?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tightening the horse hair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (touches the heel of the bow) And what do we call this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: De Sean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do we call this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wasn't here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes you were but you weren't paying attention! Do you want people to think you're stupid?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, Naeem -- tell them.

dialogue.raw_text: It's called the frog.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyone remember what this is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the fidgety girl, snaps her fingers.

direction.raw_text: Dennis's twenty students play recorder in rows of attached theatre-style seats. Dennis sits at his desk, a METRONOME ticking, and apathetically leads them in scales, using a red pen as a baton. He keeps one eye on a stack of quizzes that he's marking, stopping to circle mistakes with the pen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Roberta stands in the hallway at the open door, dismayed by Dennis' uninspired teaching. She enters and crosses to Dennis, speaking quietly to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The students immediately start to chatter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks back at Roberta, annoyed by her intrusion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She exits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me -- sorry to interrupt --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No talking!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Cooper's students have phys ed on Tuesdays.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you scheduled them for violin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must have read the schedule wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to remain polite) I don't think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I can't solve this problem for you right now. (nods to his class) I'm trying to teach.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So am I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lexi and Nick are in Brian's bed. Roberta's tucking in Lexi; he holds a toy truck with Greek writing on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta looks at Nick, then turns back to Lexi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta turns to Nick and tucks him in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns back to Nick who looks worried. She kisses him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kisses Lexi, then reaches to turn off the lamp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta nods, smiles at her sons, and exits.

dialogue.raw_text: Can I bring a puppy for show and tell tomorrow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Daddy said we could get one when we moved back to America.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about your truck? I'll bet you're the only one in school with a truck from Greece.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, he's still on his tour, so we'll just have to see but... It shouldn't be too much longer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is he gonna live with us and Brian?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, honey. We're just staying at Brian's house for a little while.

dialogue.raw_text: Good night, sweetie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! Leave it on.

direction.raw_text: Nine children stand, violins under their right arms, bows hanging down from their right hands, and try to position their feet as Roberta addresses them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks over to BENJAMIN, a white boy with glasses, and corrects his feet. She sees Lucy dancing in place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lucy nods, giggling. Roberta walks down the row of students.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She crosses to TANISHA, a sweet-natured Black girl with her hair in tiny braids, and gently pushes her belly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta turns to De Sean, who's talking to JAMES, a pudgy Black/Puerto Rican boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gently pushes Guadalupe's belly. The girl stumbles back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guadalupe tries to correct her feet. Roberta bends down to help and sees that the little girl wears LEG BRACES under her pants. Roberta stands and gestures to one of the boys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy brings the chair. Guadalupe sits, embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now take the right foot and put it on a tile. Good. Now with the other foot take a tiny step forward and put it on a line. Try to make a box with your feet --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lucy! Would you like to leave the class right now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should feel very strong -- so strong and balanced that if I wanted to knock you over I couldn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see? If you're standing strong, I can't even push you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: De Sean! James! Quiet! (as she crosses to another student) Does anyone know where Naeem is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw him this morning but he's not here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I know he's not here -- that's why I'm asking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See how I pushed you? It means your feet aren't centered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you bring over a chair? (to Guadalupe) It's probably better for you to sit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Roberta walks through a school yard filled with kids and parents picking them up. She sees Naeem and crosses to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where were you today, Naeem?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't be in violin class anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My mother won't let me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ADISA, steps INTO FRAME. She's an attractive Black woman in a dress and head scarf made of African fabric.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Adisa puts a protective arm around her son, then addresses Roberta.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks off with Naeem. He glances back at Roberta, then turns away quickly. Roberta watches after them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . ADISA My son's got more important things to do than learn dead white men's music.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're gonna learn "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star"!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ADISA How many Black classical composers can you name? How many Black classical violinists do you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That doesn't mean it's the way it should be. Naeem's learning to play music -- and that makes him feel good about himself. Why should it matter who wrote it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Mom? Can't I be in the class?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ADISA Look. I've seen this before. You white women come up here and think you can rescue our poor inner city children who never asked to be rescued in the first place. No thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Roberta attempts to read Brian's book, To Hell and Back: Interviews with Vietnam Vets, but she's distracted. She glances at her purse, then back to the book. She puts the book down and dials the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: While she waits, she looks at Brian's picture on the book jacket. There's no answer and she hangs up. She starts to straighten the already clean room, then gets her purse, takes out her wallet, and opens it to the plastic covered pictures.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Brian Turner's room, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Charles in uniform; a studio shot of the boys when they were 3 and 1; the whole family posed on the terrace of their home in Greece, a view of the ocean behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's really depressed herself now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (50's), a no-nonsense Black teacher, shows her fifth-graders a globe. She doesn't turn as Roberta enters and crosses to her. In the b.g. we see ROBERTA'S STUDENTS waiting in THE HALL.

direction.raw_text: Kids simultaneously yell out "ATLANTIC" and "PACIFIC."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta's reluctant to argue in front of the kids; she exits.

dialogue.raw_text: And which ocean is this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me... I'm here for the violin students.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (icy) You're late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a couple of minutes -- I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're having a lesson now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But this is when they have violin class!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not my problem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Janet stops walking and pulls a box cutter out of her pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Janet starts to walk away, then turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta stands there as Janet walks on ahead.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I thought all the teachers agreed to this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In theory. (to a student) Adam! I want you in my office right after lunch, you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What'd I do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Think about it! (to Roberta) Whenever you pull kids out, it's a disruption, plus it's extra work for the teacher 'cause they have to fill the kids in on what they missed. Some teachers resent it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, can't you talk to them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I took this off a second-grader this morning. I'll help you Roberta -- but I can't hold your hand here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A word of advice? When you're picking up your students, go to Alice's classroom first.

direction.raw_text: The nine children hold their violins in position as Roberta addresses them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So pretend you're driving a car and I'm the policeman and I say STOP! Thumb up, fingers straight up, flat palm. Now you be policemen, but turn your hand and make it say stop to yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: attempting this. She walks around and helps.

direction.raw_text: Some kids crack up and start joking and chatting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some of the children think about what she's saying. A couple, uncomfortable with the intensity, hold back giggles.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Embarrassed, Guadalupe corrects her position.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to himself) You're under arrest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Knock it off, De Sean! (to all) If you kids can't take this seriously, I don't want you here. I'm teaching you a difficult instrument because I respect you and have faith that you can learn it. But none of that matters if you don't have respect for yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now turn your wrist so it's flat against the fingerboard, and that's how you'll set up your hand...

direction.raw_text: At the small kitchen table, Nick does homework and Lexi puts stickers in a sticker book. Roberta's cooking dinner; she grabs a potholder and checks on a bubbling lasagna in the oven. The PHONE RINGS and she answers it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her face falls as she hears the voice. She holds onto the counter to steady herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta closes the oven and gathers her courage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We watch Roberta's body collapse into a sense of overwhelming relief. FOLLOW HER as she steps into THE HALLWAY, then stretches the phone into:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) (calm, detached) I'm back in the States. I'm at my parents.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She half-closes the door, leans against the sink and starts to cry.

direction.raw_text: Silence.

dialogue.raw_text: (through tears) We've missed you so much, Charles. The boys... they can't wait for you to come home... I know we'll have a lot to work out and it won't be easy right away, but we're gonna get through this, you know? We're a family and we belong together and -- CHARLES (O.S.) (more emotive than before) Bobbi -- stop, O.K.? Just stop.

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) It is. (beat) It's over between us too, Bobbi.

direction.raw_text: devastated. ANGLE on NICK, watching her through the door.

direction.raw_text: Brian's on the phone with Roberta. He's in a t-shirt and sweats, and his papers are scattered on the bed.

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) He wouldn't even talk about it! No explanations, no discussion...

direction.raw_text: Roberta in Brian's living room. She's extremely agitated and her eyes are puffy from crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This embarrasses her, then pisses her off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I can't believe you were still holding out hope. The guy hasn't called you or the kids in three months -- I thought you'd moved on.

dialogue.raw_text: I never said that.

dialogue.raw_text: No? Maybe not with words.

dialogue.raw_text: You know what? I shouldn't have called you. This was a mistake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no -- I'm sorry. Look, I know it hurts, but you're gonna get through this, Roberta -- you will.

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know yet.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta stands and watches Nick and Lexi sleep. She lies down beside them and closes her eyes.

direction.raw_text: As Janet turns to walk off, Roberta crosses to her.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why would she give you fifty dollars?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To buy breakfast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know how hard your mother works? Do you think it's right for you steal from her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well let's go call her right now and ask her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need to speak to you. It's important.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It'll have to wait. (to the boy) Come on. In my office.

direction.raw_text: Guadalupe sighs, then hands Roberta the violin.

direction.raw_text: Roberta looks at her sadly and puts the violin in its case.

direction.raw_text: Guadalupe takes this in.

direction.raw_text: Roberta laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guadalupe nods. Roberta holds out the violin case. Guadalupe lunges forward and hugs her around the waist. Roberta awkwardly accepts the hug, startled and touched by it, and strokes the girl's hair. Guadalupe lets go, takes the violin and exits. HOLD ON ROBERTA as she absorbs what just happened. JANET pokes her head into the room.

direction.raw_text: Janet looks at her curiously, then exits.

dialogue.raw_text: Guadalupe? What are you doing here?

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's one of the greatest violinists in the world, and he has problems with his legs too. He walks with two canes -- but he still makes the most beautiful music.

dialogue.raw_text: He has to.

dialogue.raw_text: He was your student?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. But if he was, I'd tell him the same thing I'm telling you. You shouldn't quit something just because it's hard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I can't stand strong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Standing strong doesn't only mean using your legs. You can stand strong on the inside too. (beat) Know what I mean?

dialogue.raw_text: You wanted to speak to me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Umm -- that's O.K. It's taken care of.

direction.raw_text: Roberta walks around an empty, rundown apartment, her expression somber. Crayon markings on the walls, cigarette burns on the floors, a filthy bathroom and kitchen. An older Puerto Rican woman stands back as Roberta inspects the place. Roberta wipes grease off one of the windows.

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is just for you and your boys?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No husband? No boyfriend?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.

direction.raw_text: He gives her a tempera PAINTING of a man's face, the background decorated with glued-on macaroni. It says DADDY.

direction.raw_text: He runs off. Roberta exhales, sits down alone on a bench and takes out her lunch. She smiles at ALICE CROWLEY and another TEACHER but they cross to another bench. ISABEL VASQUEZ (25) approaches, a lively Puerto Rican woman with a strong New York accent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sits down beside Roberta, takes out her lunch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta smiles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look what I made you, Mommy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (covering her discomfort) That is so beautiful!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whatsa matter -- you got cooties?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Apparently.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take my chances. (extends a hand) Isabel Vasquez. Second grade.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Roberta Demetras. I'm the -- ISABEL Violin teacher. I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it my imagination, or does everyone hate me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's hard to fit in when you're doing a special program. People figure you're not gonna be here very long, so why make the effort? (beat) It may take a while for folks to warm up, but nobody hates you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sotto) What about Alice Crowley?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sotto) A) she thinks the violin's a waste of time... and B) -- she's a bitch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And then there's Dennis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Music Man. You've had the bodacity to threaten his private little empire -- not to mention the fact that you messed up his sacred scheduling chart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How come you're being nice to me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ulterior motives. I want my daughter in your class next year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I'm here next year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is on the wall, along with a crayon drawing of himself, Roberta, and Nick in front of a house.

direction.raw_text: looks out the window. She's gotten some used furniture, cleaned the place, and it's less depressing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: OUT THE WINDOW On the street below, three prostitutes stand at the corner. Two men sit on a stoop, smoking a joint, and in a parked car, three men seem to be making a drug deal. One of the buildings on the street is burned out, missing a front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nick, in his pajamas, enters and crosses to his mother. She smiles at him and they both look out the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta smiles and puts her arm around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta tenses up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta looks at him, concerned that he's not responding to her news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat as she contemplates whether to push or not, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him, taken aback by the question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta, overcome with emotion, can barely answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CAMERA moves behind them as they continue to look out the window, and we see Nick move away from his mother.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In Greece, we could see the ocean. Remember?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I remember. And the fishing boats...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the octopuses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is Daddy coming here soon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that's something I've been wanting to talk to you about. Daddy's not gonna live with us anymore. You and Lexi will have special times when you stay with him, like at Christmas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you tell the birthday story?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you want to talk about what I told you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to hear the birthday story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was the day of Grandpa's birthday, and I was sad because he had died a few months back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you knew I'd be born that day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So I packed a bag and got all ready -- NICK And Daddy laughed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said, "It's my father's birthday, and the baby's gonna be born today."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He didn't believe you. But I was born. The same day as Grandpa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was a happy day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was Daddy happy too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course he was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why is he leaving me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's not leaving you, Nick. He loves you and Lexi very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why can't he live here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (struggling) It's very hard to explain... Sometimes things happen between grown-ups... and they just can't be together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The kids play "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star" and they sound awful. Roberta looks disgusted as she leads them.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Again? You told me you went to the hospital last week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yeah. Maybe it was last week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lucy -- you sounded the worst of all. Have you practiced?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not? You can't be in this class if you don't practice!

dialogue.raw_text: My grandma got mugged.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. I'm sorry. Is she O.K.?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She died.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm really sorry, Lucy. (tries to get her bearings) Just do the best you can.

direction.raw_text: A group of kids stand together with their violins and chat. Roberta exits the building and they greet her. She waves back, but she's clearly still upset by her interaction with Lucy. She sees Naeem and his mother and approaches them.

direction.raw_text: Naeem nods and moves off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Adisa takes this in. Roberta exits. Mrs. Adisa looks for Naeem and sees him watching the violin students, longing to be among them. She watches her son with compassion.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Roberta.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Naeem. Can I talk to your mom for a minute?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I didn't come up here to rescue anybody. I'm a single mother and I needed a job. And I know you think you're protecting your son, but you're not. I mean, what if Arthur Ashe's mother had stopped him from playing tennis because it's a "white man's game"? (beat) The important thing is that when Naeem plays music, his whole face lights up. You should see him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Roberta and the boys shop in a colorful outdoor produce market in their neighborhood. The boys suddenly rush over to A MAN sitting on the ground with mixed-breed PUPPIES in a cardboard box. The boys pet them excitedly. Roberta watches her sons; they're happier than she's seen them in ages.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A brown puppy is jumping all over Nick and Lexi who laugh delightedly. Roberta is putting down newspapers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boys are oblivious to her -- they're in heaven.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We all have to take turns cleaning up, O.K.?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to herself) Yeah, right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Roberta's SCREAMING at the kids as they play "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They stop playing. Tanisha raises her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tanisha nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some of the kids crack up.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Naeem happily runs to the extra violins at the front of the room; Mrs. Adisa nods to Roberta with a look of gratitude, then exits. Roberta crosses back to the front of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They begin again, and we see Naeem take out a violin and join in. As they play, Roberta's ears perk up at something she's hearing. She crosses to Lucy.

direction.raw_text: Lucy hesitates, thinking she's in trouble. She plays a jazz variation of the song. Roberta smiles.

direction.raw_text: Lucy beams.

dialogue.raw_text: First finger on the E! Three -- two -- one -- open! (to a white girl with pigtails) Wrong string, Becky! We've done this fourteen times! And look at your nails! You're supposed to cut them for violin class! O.K, everybody stop! It sounds horrible! I can't believe how bad it sounds!

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wore a skirt just like it on Monday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, Tanisha -- I don't think that's such an important question. (to class) O.K. Let's try --

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's O.K. (to Naeem) Why don't you go grab one of my spare violins?

dialogue.raw_text: (to class) Let's try it again.

dialogue.raw_text: What are you playing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twinkle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to class) Everyone stop! (to Lucy) Let me hear.

dialogue.raw_text: Did someone teach you that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's really great, Lucy. I'm proud of you.

dialogue.raw_text: (to class) All of you -- try it.

direction.raw_text: Roberta sits opposite Janet and MRS. LAMB, a white woman in her 30's.

direction.raw_text: Janet raises her eyebrows at this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gives Roberta a long hard look. Roberta nods.

dialogue.raw_text: . LAMB You're shouting at them. All the time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not all the time. But if they don't listen -- MRS. LAMB Didn't you tell them that they were making their parents sick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That wasn't exactly what I said -- MRS. LAMB I'm raising Becky in a supportive atmosphere. I don't send her to school to be abused.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just trying to discipline them. If they're gonna learn an instrument, they need to take it seriously -- JANET I think what Mrs. Lamb is trying to say, Roberta, is that you're a little too harsh. I'm sure you might be able to soften some of your comments to the children?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Roberta listens to the students play "Go Tell Aunt Rhody" -- badly. They finish and stare at her, afraid of her response.

direction.raw_text: They look at her in disbelief, then look at each other.

direction.raw_text: The boy nervously shakes his head no.

direction.raw_text: James nods. The kids are baffled by her politeness.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kids laugh.

direction.raw_text: The kids laugh again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that was... that was pretty good... that wasn't too bad...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It wasn't? I thought we stunk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't put it that way... You all just need to practice a bit more. (to James) James, have you practiced this week?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you please try a little harder for next week?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. Just do the best you can.

dialogue.raw_text: Like what?

dialogue.raw_text: Nice.

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you want a nice teacher?

dialogue.raw_text: I already got nice teachers. You added some variety.

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. We like you better the way you used to be.

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. (to Becky) What about you, Becky?

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. This is even worse. You're acting weird now.

direction.raw_text: Christmas MUZAK plays in the b.g. as Roberta kisses and hugs Lexi and Nick goodbye. A FLIGHT ATTENDANT stands nearby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lexi looks upset; Nick is stoic. Roberta hugs them one last time. The FLIGHT ATTENDANT steps forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The FLIGHT ATTENDANT escorts them into the jet way. Roberta holds back tears as they get further away from her. At the last moment, Lexi turns and waves; Nick does not. Roberta waves, tears starting to fall, and the boys disappear from sight. She observes all the families travelling together, and feels like the loneliest person in the airport.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Can't you come with us? Please?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Honey, I told you. This is Daddy's special time with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take good care of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Roberta enters her apartment, back from the airport, and double-locks the door behind her. You can see on her face that she's dreading the emptiness. She crosses to a small Christmas tree, obviously decorated by her and the boys, and plugs in the tiny blinking lights. It's not exactly Rockefeller Center. She turns on the T.V., playing IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE. She crosses to the kitchen, then returns with a carton of eggnog, a glass, and a bottle of rum. She sits down on the couch, pours herself some eggnog, adds rum, adds more rum, goes back into the kitchen, returns with nutmeg, sprinkles some on top, then drinks. She sighs, glancing miserably at the tree and the T.V. Pathetic. She couldn't look any less festive if she tried. There's a KNOCK on the DOOR. Roberta gets up and warily approaches the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks through the peephole, then quickly unlocks the door and opens it, revealing BRIAN, giving her a big smile. He looks sexy as hell (even with a silly lit-up Santa Claus pin on his leather jacket), and he holds a long-stemmed red rose in one hand, and a Christmas present in the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta's thrilled and relieved to see him. She embraces him, and they kiss passionately.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Santa Claus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ON plaster walls being knocked down with sledgehammers. REVEAL Brian, Roberta, and a couple of workmen knocking down the walls in an old brownstone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A mild winter day. Roberta, covered with plaster dust and overheated from working, leans against a car and drinks a beer. The three-story brick building has some graffiti on it and is badly in need of a paint job; there are a few broken windows, and the front stairs need repairing. WORKMEN file in and out. We can see from the STREET SIGNS that we're on 118th STREET, a few houses off FIRST AVENUE. Brian (also dust-covered), Nick and Lexi toss around a football. LAWRENCE (6), a Black boy who lives next door, joins them. Brian crosses to Roberta, sweaty and out of breath. He takes a swig of her beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She laughs and they kiss.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: .K., enough goofing off -- back to work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You trying to kill me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: comes up the street with a bag of take-out food. She casts a dubious glance at the lovers.

direction.raw_text: Roberta rolls her eyes. O.S. a car BACKFIRES.

direction.raw_text: Lawrence nods and she hands him a sandwich. Roberta smiles at her mother's gesture. The kids move off to Lawrence's front steps and Assunta gives Roberta and Brian sandwiches.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I was the only person in the whole coffee shop not speaking Spanish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lawrence.

dialogue.raw_text: You hungry, Lawrence?

direction.raw_text: Roberta locks her jaw, not wanting to believe that she's right.

dialogue.raw_text: I still don't understand the rush.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Having my own place will make me feel like I'm really starting my life again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But if you invested your divorce settlement, you could buy something nice someday. It's bad enough that you've been renting in this neighborhood, but to lock yourself into a mortgage -- ROBERTA (snapping) Mama, please. Just stop!

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, O.K.? Besides, if things keep going well, I'm sure eventually Brian will move in with us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much do you know about this man?

dialogue.name: dialogue

Roberta cues them and they play the next note in perfect unison. An involuntary smile lights on DE SEAN's face. They finish the song, the audience applauds, and Roberta turns to face them. She lights up when she sees how thrilled Janet looks, and Janet in turn raises her hands higher as she applauds Roberta.

direction.raw_text: Roberta stands in front of a classroom of twenty cute first- graders -- mostly Black and Latino, a few white -- sitting on the floor, chatting excitedly. dialogue.raw_text: Excessed. (beat) They specifically said that my violin program has to go.

dialogue.raw_text: (points to her phone) I've been on this phone for the past three days trying to "do something" -- the District office can't even stand the sound of my voice. Believe me, there are some people around here I'd much rather get rid of. But as far as the Board's concerned, violin classes are not a priority.

dialogue.raw_text: I don't have the power here, Roberta. I'm so sorry.

direction.raw_text: -- A foil-covered plate with a note on top: DO YOU KNOW ANYONE AT THE NEW YORK TIMES?

direction.raw_text: Dan lifts up the foil to reveal a large piece of LASAGNA.

direction.raw_text: play "We Shall Overcome" and it's incredibly moving. Nick's on cello, Lexi plays piano. ROBERTA proudly leads the children. At the side of the stage, we see DOROTHEA photographing the concert. THE CAMERA PANS THE AUDIENCE of teary-eyed parents, many of them with CAM CORDERS. We FIND Ramon's family. Manuelo is riverted by his son's playing, and he starts to cry. Concepcion knows this without looking. She takes his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stands along the side and her eyes start to fill with tears. She tries to stay composed, then discreetly exits the auditorium. The song ends and the audience APPLAUDS, rising from their seats, including ASSUNTA (now 65), next to ISABEL and DAN. Someone remains seated: a REPORTER (40's), sitting beside Dan and taking notes. The STUDENTS bow, then point to Roberta who bows and takes the stage. She gestures for people to sit. A beginner student brings her flowers. Roberta kisses her, then approaches the mike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The parents stand and applaud. We see the REPORTER writing quickly. Dorothea snaps more pictures. Roberta extends an arm towards the kids, directing the applause at them. Ramon gives her a thumbs up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to the audience) The beautiful concert that you just heard could be the last concert of the East Harlem Violin Program. The Board of Education and the District Superintendent don't think that music is important for our children. But they're wrong -- and they're in for a fight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is vacuuming the living room while Assunta dusts. Extra chairs are set up in the living room in preparation for a meeting. The doorbell RINGS.

dialogue.raw_text: Someone's early.

direction.raw_text: to the DOOR. She opens it, revealing JANET, who's carrying two bags of groceries. Assunta's demeanor instantly cools when she sees her. In the b.g. Roberta sees Janet and turns off the vacuum cleaner.

direction.raw_text: She holds up two wedges of cheese.

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Assunta. How are you?

dialogue.raw_text: Ma!

dialogue.raw_text: Why not? We've gotta figure out a way to fight this. (as she arranges crackers on a plate) After ten years, Roberta, I can't imagine walking through those hallways and not hearing that off-key, screechy, scratchy, nails-on-the- blackboard violin music.

dialogue.raw_text: Sounds like a plan.

dialogue.raw_text: (half to herself) It better be a good concert.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This can't happen! We've sold tickets! We've done publicity! The concert's in three weeks!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been on the phone all morning calling other theaters. Nothing's available.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just keep looking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Fiddlefest kids are crammed into Roberta's house, (including De Sean, Guadalupe, Ramon, Vanessa, Shandra, Carlos, Thomas, Stephanie, Amanda, Kenny, and Simon), rehearsing "Orange Blossom Special." They play badly. Rachel helps Roberta correct students.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kids look at each other, daunted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta looks at her, and then notices the despondent looks on many of the kids' faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one raises a hand. Roberta takes this in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stop! Someone's playing the wrong notes! And you shouldn't need your music anymore! Except for the Bach Double, everything has to be memorized by next rehearsal!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you sound like you're sleepwalking. Your heart's not even in it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe 'cause we don't have a place for the concert.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you're right. This might all be for nothing. So we can either keep on rehearsing in case we find a place -- or we can just... give up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Am I hearing right? Did you use the words "give up"? (to the students) Let's take a vote. How many of you want to give up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See? You taught us well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It's early morning. Lexi cooks breakfast while Nick and Roberta look at scribbled-on, marked-up lists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all look depressed. Lexi places an equally depressing- looking stack of pancakes on the table. There's a BANGING on the door, startling everyone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nick opens the door and Dorothea rushes in, out of breath, talking a mile a minute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dorothea grins from ear to ear, Nick and Lexi whoop and holler, and all wait for Roberta to jump up and down for joy -- but she looks stricken.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What about in the Bronx?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's nothing. (beat) Why don't you just do it in one of the schools? It'll be a lot smaller but -- ROBERTA We won't make enough money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about postponing it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Itzhak and Arnold are booked all summer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) It's Dorothea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have good news -- really good news. Arnold got a call from his friend Wally Scheur who heard about us losing the Y and wanted to see how he could help -- and then Wally had this brilliant idea and called his friend Isaac Stern and it's all arranged! We have a new place for Fiddlefest!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Carnegie Hall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (panicked) Carnegie Hall?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: revolving slowly.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: UPPER BALCONIES -- THE LOWER BALCONIES -- THE ORCHESTRA SEATS

direction.raw_text: She stands on the empty stage, gazing at the ceiling as she slowly turns around. She's holding her violin case. She looks at the UPPER BALCONIES -- THE LOWER BALCONIES -- THE ORCHESTRA SEATS. Her footsteps echo as she walks towards the front of the stage, then stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can see her imagining the audience on the night of the concert. She can't believe her eyes. A beat, and she looks around to make sure she's alone. She takes out her violin, takes a deep breath as she looks out towards her "audience," then starts to play the second violin part of the Bach Double Concerto. Suddenly, there's the SOUND of a stage door opening. Roberta stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta turns to see ISAAC STERN approaching her. She's completely flustered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta takes this in, relating it to her own struggle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isaac nods, then touches her shoulder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Incredible sound in this room, no?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my god -- Isaac Stern.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must be Roberta.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you so much for helping us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking out at the hall) Would you believe in 1960, they tried to tear this place down? They wanted to replace it with a bright red skyscraper -- we called it "the red terror."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're kidding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We had to fight like hell, but with a lot of help, we saved Carnegie Hall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If it's all right with you, I'd like to play in your concert. Maybe bring a couple of friends...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, of course! That would be great!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't give up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Roberta pours nervous energy into her cappuccino, adding cinnamon, chocolate, and sugar, stirring loudly. Dan sits across from her, observing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He offers her a forkful of some decadent-looking chocolate cake, but she shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes this in, looks at him gratefully and puts her hand over his. He strokes her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta looks at him with trepidation. Dan takes another forkful of his cake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta laughs. Dan smiles, glad he got her to lighten up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I just don't see how I'm gonna do this. It's huge. It's gigantic! It's Carnegie Hall! And listen to this: now Isaac Stern wants to play with us -- Diane Monroe, Michael Tree -- there's other people calling -- DAN That's fantastic!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fantastic? I'll never get the kids up to speed in time, I'll never get myself up to speed. I'm gonna be playing side by side with the world's greatest violinists.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And "the world's greatest violinists" are playing side by side with you because they want to help you win this fight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, but... you don't understand. Maybe there's a good reason why I never made it as a violinist -- maybe I just can't cut it. I keep blaming it on not having enough early training, but if I were talented, if I had a gift -- DAN But you do have a gift. You're gonna put thirty East Harlem kids on stage at Carnegie Hall not because they're prodigies, but because you got them to stick with something that's hard as hell and to strive for excellence -- which, by the way, I certainly wasn't striving for when I was their age. Not to mention the other ten years' worth of students whose lives were changed because of you. That's your talent, Roberta.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm scared.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. (beat) And by the way, I happen to think you're a pretty good violinist too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've barely heard me play.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've heard enough to know you're gonna do just fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Besides, no one's gonna be paying attention to your playing anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Fiddlefest kids (including Ramon, Shandra, Vanessa, De Sean, Naeem, Guadalupe, Lucy, Simon, Stephanie, Amanda and Kenny -- but RACHEL is absent) stand outside the locked school gate, waiting for Roberta. Some of the kids have their violins out of the cases, tuning them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kids laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A few kids start playing "CAN-CAN." It catches on, and more of them join in. PASSERSBY stop to listen, and some drop change into the open cases. RAMON and a couple of other kids grin at this.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Teacher's late. I think she should be dropped, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. I don't think we should let her play in Fiddlefest!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: steps in front of the kids as he plays, and begins an uncanny imitation of Roberta:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kids crack up, but a few spot ROBERTA heading quickly up the street. Carlos is oblivious to this -- and no one signals him that Roberta's watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carlos senses a presence and turns to see Roberta. A tense beat as he awaits her reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carlos freezes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta nods, and addresses the kids as she unlocks the gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kids start filing in. Rachel comes up the street and catches up to Roberta.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta sees how distressed Rachel looks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel shakes her head no, then starts to cry a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hands Roberta her violin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rachel looks anguished. Roberta moves closer and touches her arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta looks at her, pained, then hugs her. Rachel quickly kisses Roberta goodbye and exits. Roberta watches her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: More bow! To the frog! You sound terrible! I can't believe how terrible you sound!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're gonna make everyone in Carnegie Hall sick to their stomachs! That's right, they're gonna pay a thousand dollars a ticket and you're gonna make them throw up on their gowns and tuxedos!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in all seriousness) If you're gonna imitate me, do it right. (corrects his posture) Shoulders back. Violin higher. Check your feet. There. (beat) G'head, Carlos. Continue.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, that's O.K. You can take it from here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's right, by the way. You do sound terrible, and you are gonna make everyone in Carnegie Hall sick to their stomachs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need to talk to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to kids) I'll be right in. Start on Minuet One. (to Rachel) What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're moving away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? Where are you moving?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking downward) It's a secret... My father... he's been hurting my mom... We have to leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gently) Has he been hurting you too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry about Julliard... and the concert.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep it. Take it with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No... I don't want to play anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?! You can't give up violin, Rachel -- it's a part of you. A very important part.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please honey. Just take it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Roberta leads De Sean, Naeem, Guadalupe, Lucy, Stephanie, Thomas, Carlos, Erica and Nicholas in the Bach Double Concerto. The other kids watch. Roberta's on the edge of hysteria. She signals the players to stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kids say "the world's greatest violinists" along with her -- they've obviously been hearing this a lot. Roberta glares at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stops, takes a breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the kids nod. A few beats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She crosses to take a look at her music, and the kids exchange looks that say, "Oh shit. What did we just promise?"
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, no! Accent the up bow after the slurred notes and then it'll get you off of those slurred notes! You Double Concerto kids need to be working harder! This is the grand finale of the concert! You're each gonna be sharing a music stand with one of the world's greatest violinists!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think we should forget the Bach Double. (to the other kids) And you guys are never gonna get Minuet One. I think we should drop that too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! We can do it, Roberta!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And we'll get the Bach Double. We will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's gonna be O.K., Roberta.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (vulnerable) You think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: .K... (not believing it) It's gonna be O.K.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - DAY 1. Carlos practices violin against the fence around River East School. In the b. g., his buddies make fun of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Shandra practices in a school stairwell, ignoring a boy who pulls one of her braids as he passes by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Stephanie practices at a bus stop, her eyes closed, then looks up and realizes she's just missed her bus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Ramon practices in his living room, his father watching attentively, then helping him lift the violin higher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Vanessa practices in a crowded school hallway, frustrated as kids keep bumping into her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Roberta, in her nightgown, practices in front of her refrigerator in the middle of the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pandemonium. Nick and Lexi, both in tuxes, are doing several tasks at once while Roberta, in a simple black velvet dress and stockinged feet, tries to put on her makeup but keeps poking her head out of the bathroom, giving orders. Allegra BARKS outside the back door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Nick -- did you feed Allegra?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fixing Lexi's tie) Yes, Mom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lexi, can you make sure the charts are still in my bag?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I already checked, Mom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Check again, please. And look for my repair kit too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: descends the staircase, dressed in a formal dress. She holds a small jewelry box and heads for the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta sticks her head out and picks the earrings. Assunta enters the small bathroom to work on her own makeup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nick rolls his eyes and runs upstairs while Lexi organizes things by the door: Nick's cello, Roberta's papers, extra violins. Roberta rushes out of the bathroom, adjusting the earrings. She starts compulsively straightening the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nick comes running down the stairs with the violins and stares in disbelief at Roberta fluffing a couch pillow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He throws the pillow onto the couch. Roberta heads upstairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bert, which earrings you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nick? Get two more violins.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've already got two -- how many emergencies can there be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get three more. And make sure a couple of them are half-size.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lexi -- can you call about the car again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mom, they're not gonna forget to send a car!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just straightening a little.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're insane, you know that? (grabs the pillow) Finish getting dressed!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Carlos adjusts his tuxedo. We see the reflection of his baseball bat, glove and trophies in the room behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guadalupe's mom pins up her braid, then steps back to look at her daughter, radiant in a floral gown. Her mom starts to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beverly puts rhinestone-studded barrettes in Shandra's hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's in a sharp black suit and looks very dapper. WIDER - Manuelo and Concepcion stand back to admire him, then Manuelo straightens Ramon's tie, brimming with pride over his son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nick and Assunta look towards the stairs. Roberta comes running down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns around, revealing a RIP on the back of the dress, next to the zipper. The DOORBELL RINGS.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Can you believe this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It can't be time! Is it time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll sew it in the car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Roberta, Assunta and the boys step outside, amazed to see a STRETCH LIMOUSINE double-parked in front, a CHAUFFEUR waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta's open-mouthed. She leads her entourage towards the limo. THE NEIGHBORS come out of their houses to watch. Some lean out windows, gawking. Ad libs... "Who's that?" "It's the Violin Lady!" LAWRENCE, dressed in a tux, gives Lexi a high sign. The chauffeur helps Roberta and Assunta into the limo while Nick and Lexi start to load the instruments into the trunk.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: See? I told you they'd send a car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Roberta sits down beside Assunta and turns around so Assunta can mend the tear in her dress. Assunta partially unzips the dress and starts stitching it from the inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Assunta stitches, remembering, and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta contemplates this. A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her last stitch finished, Assunta rips the needle from the thread.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Mama.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry about it. You rip -- I sew.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not just for that. (beat) Thank you for getting me out of bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't thank me -- thank Charles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charles?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If that jerk hadn't of left you, none of this would've happened.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Charles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CARNEGIE HALL - BACK STAGE - NIGHT The kids and their parents are practically boiling over with excitement. Last minute kisses, violin tunings, and clothing adjustments take place throughout the room. The boys are in suits or tuxes, the girls in velvet or flowered dresses, some with bows in their hair, some with their hair up in buns. Roberta tries to take a head count, Dorothea confers with a stage manager, Assunta fixes a boy's tie, and Janet helps one girl with her hair, stopping in the middle to button the back of another girl's dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Janet looks at her, concerned.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where's Vanessa? Has anyone seen Vanessa?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll call her house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - Roberta sees MRS. ADISA enter the room with Naeem. The two women walk towards each other and embrace. As they start to chat, Roberta suddenly sees someone and excuses herself: BRIAN is walking towards her, wearing a tux. They smile at each other, but Roberta's clearly a bit shaken to see him. They're not quite sure how to greet each other -- he takes her hand, and then kisses her on the cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Congratulations.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I knew you'd get here sooner or later. I'm glad I'm here to see it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Guadalupe shyly approaches Itzhak Perlman, her mother behind her, silently encouraging her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles at her and they shake hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Guadalupe introduces him to her mother, CARLOS approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Itzhak Perlman laughs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, Mr. Perlman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (extends a hand) I'm Guadalupe. I've wanted to meet you for a long time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A pleasure to meet you, Guadalupe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You nervous, Mr. Perlman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Should I be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Us kids are gonna be great -- I don't know about you guys. How much did you practice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Roberta talks to Janet with a worried expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A Carnegie Hall staff person in a suit enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The room electrifies with nerves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You called Vanessa's father and mother?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No answer at either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Half hour call! It's now half hour call! So pace yourself accordingly. Don't get more than thirty minutes worth of nervous!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: rushes into the room with her father. She's out of breath, her stocking has a big run in it, and she's in tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boys rush over to the extra violins and look to find the right size.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta comforts her and Janet moves in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They stole the car!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . KLEIN With the violin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my God. (calling) Nick, Lexi -- NICK Done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (crying) And then when we were getting a taxi, I fell down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon honey -- let's get you cleaned up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: enters with a bouquet of long-stemmed red roses. He's in a tux and looks very handsome. He crosses to Roberta, hands her the flowers, and they hug.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're glowing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's terror.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The hall is filling to capacity as people take their seats, the room buzzing with voices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CARNEGIE HALL staff person enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tension in the room shoots sky high.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . WE NOW HAVE FIVE MINUTES.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Janet stands onstage and addresses the audience.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When I became the principal of Central Park East Elementary, I envisioned a school where children could fulfill their highest potential, despite the challenges of poverty and racism. Ten years ago, Roberta Guaspari walked into my office because she needed a job, and because she had a vision that any child could learn the violin. We put our dreams together and created the East Harlem Violin Program which has helped more than a thousand students expand their vision of what's possible in their lives. When a program like this is cut, our children's future is compromised. I want to thank you for your support. Enjoy the concert.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In the b.g. we hear the audience APPLAUDING Janet. Roberta holds up her hands to quiet down the anxious students.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They become quiet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kids breathe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She pats her heart.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Everyone -- attention please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want you all to take a second just to breathe, O.K.? Deep breath.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I would like you all to play with your heart, all right? Play like I know you can play. You'll be wonderful. Watch me, don't look out in the audience -- you don't need to be afraid. It's gonna be really wonderful. So play -- play from here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The kids head out towards the stage, the APPLAUSE getting louder as they get closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of the children on stage, in their positions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some of the kids look awestruck by the audience; one subtly waves hi to her family. Roberta walks out to APPLAUSE. She bows to the audience, turns to the kids, signals them with a slight nod and the BACH MINUET ONE begins. We've heard it in all phases, and now it is flawless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the STUDENTS watching her: VANESSA, wearing a corsage; SIMON in his red bow tie; SHANDRA in black velvet with pearls; NAEEM standing proud and tall, DE SEAN in dreadlocks and a tux; RAMON playing from his heart...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isaac Stern, Itzhak Perlman, Michael Tree, Arnold Steinhardt, Diane Monroe, Karen Briggs and Mark O'Connor wait back stage, chatting and listening to the kids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The students finish MINUET ONE. There's an exquisite moment of silence, then APPLAUSE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Country fiddler MARK O'CONNOR plays ORANGE BLOSSOM SPECIAL with the kids. He improvises, surprising them as his violin makes the sound of a TRAIN moving through a tunnel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: smiles, awed by this -- but he remains calm and professional.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the guest violinists head for the stage, we hear their names over a mike, mixed with APPLAUSE:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Isaac Stern, Itzhak Perlman, Arnold Steinhardt, Diane Monroe, Michael Tree, Mark O'Connor and Karen Briggs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: of the six guest violinists on stage for the Grand Finale, each one sharing a music stand with a student. Roberta nods, and they begin THE BACH DOUBLE CONCERTO. She turns to face the audience as she joins them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the performers and students: NAAEM shares a stand with ARNOLD STEINHARDT; ISAAC STERN stands and plays with GUADALUPE, sitting beside him; ITZHAK PERLMAN sits and plays next to CARLOS, standing beside him; MICHAEL TREE plays beside DE SEAN; DIANE MONROE plays beside LUCY; KAREN BRIGGS plays beside THOMAS, and MARK O'CONNOR plays beside STEPHANIE. NICK plays cello; LEXI plays the piano behind them; and, playing with her own solo music stand, ROBERTA. Their expressions are serious and passionate, broken by occasional smiles lighting on faces: Isaac Stern... Lucy... Carlos... Itzhak Perlman... Diane Monroe... De Sean. The song finishes and the APPLAUSE begins. The OTHER FIDDLEFEST PLAYERS come out from back stage, RAMON in front, and join the rest. More applause. The CAMERA PULLS BACK TO INCLUDE the audience facing the stage, then REVERSES to show the audience standing in the orchestra and balconies. We see the students' PARENTS; JANET, ISABEL and their families; ASSUNTA, LAWRENCE and DOROTHEA; DAN; CONCEPCION, MANUELO and their sons; BRIAN; and DENNIS -- even he can't stop himself from applauding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to the stage where the students and guest violinists bow... and MOVE IN CLOSER on ROBERTA in her moment of triumph.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta addresses the audience. Her voice is strong but softer around the edges; she is a woman in a state of grace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The APPLAUSE is DEAFENING, then slowly diminishes as we:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We're all here tonight because we have a bigger mission: to take the magical spirit of tonight's concert with us out into the world, and to fight for music and art to be a part of every child's education. Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Roberta addresses ten first-graders sitting in a circle on the floor. She points to the horsehair on her bow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roberta and the kids laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy smiles and shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One girl raises her hand with urgency.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy points to the frog of the bow and Roberta smiles. And as she continues her lesson, her voice recedes and we:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And this? What's this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The frog hair?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you ever see a frog with hair?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's horsehair!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. (to the boy) But you're right, there is a frog. Can you show me where it is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ooh! I know!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sssh -- let him answer.
dialogue.name: dialogue
